title-group.article-title: Patterns of Cognitive and Fine Motor Deficits in a Case of Dandy-Walker Continuum

abstract.p: Cerebellar vermian hypoplasia in the context of Dandy-Walker complex is a relatively common disorder associated with a variety of cognitive and behavioral deficits in addition to impairment in motor control. Few studies, however, have examined the neuropsychological profiles of children with isolated hypoplasias of the cerebellum. Herein, we report a 6-year-old girl with Dandy-Walker continuum presenting with mild mental retardation and an inability to produce intelligible speech, despite adequate comprehension of single items and simple instructions. She was able to articulate vowels but not consonants, and fine motor function was deficient. Visual memory was intact for single items but not for multiple items, and visuospatial perception was impaired. An inability to form intelligible speech is not typically reported in cases of isolated vermian hypoplasia. The case extends our knowledge of the phenotypes associated with cerebellar hypoplasia and its relation to fine motor and articulatory control.

body.p: The term Dandy-Walker complex describes a continuum of anomalies of the posterior fossa, which are classified on the basis of the size of the posterior fossa, the presence of cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle and the degree of vermian hypoplasia. At the most severe end of the continuum is Dandy-Walker malformation, which is characterized by the presence of a large posterior fossa cyst with open communication with the fourth ventricle, complete or partial agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, and enlargement of the posterior fossa with elevation of the tentorium. The Dandy-Walker variant, a less severe anomaly, is characterized by variable vermian hypoplasia and a normal-sized posterior fossa with a small cystic cavity that communicates with the fourth ventricle. 1,2 Dandy-Walker malformation and variant are relatively common, estimated to occur in 1/11 574 births in one population-based study, but with 66% mortality because of the high rate of associated anomalies. 3

Survivors of Dandy-Walker malformation manifest severe neurocognitive deficits, global or motor developmental delay, hypotonia, speech delay, ocular signs, 4
–7 and autistic features, 7 but children with isolated Dandy-Walker variant or isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia have a more favorable outcome. 1,8 Isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia is characterized by partial absence of the inferior portion of the cerebellar vermis with normal- or near normal-shaped cerebellar hemispheres and a normal-sized posterior fossa. It is sometimes referred to as Dandy-Walker variant despite the fact that it lacks a cystic fourth ventricle. 9 However, it has been recommended that the term Dandy-Walker variant be abandoned, given its multiple and variable definitions and the term isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia
9,10 or the term Dandy-Walker continuum be used. Because the term Dandy-Walker continuum describes a spectrum of anomalies that have in common the presence of a large retrocerebellar cyst associated with a vermian defect that are thought to have a common pathogenesis, 11,12 it is used instead, in the present study.

Increasing evidence indicates that the cerebellum participates in more than motor control and that cerebellar/vermian hypoplasia is associated with a variety of cognitive and behavioral deficits. 4,5,7,8,13,14 However, only a few studies have examined the neuropsychological profiles of children with isolated hypoplasias of the cerebellum (isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia or Dandy-Walker continuum), and the majority of such studies are limited to retrospective evaluation of charts or pediatrician reports. 1,5,7,15,16 Because of the distinctive ontogeny of the cerebellum, the investigation of the impact of vermian hypoplasia on neuropsychological functioning offers a valuable window into the role of this structure in cognitive and linguistic development.

Herein, we report a 6-year-old girl with the diagnosis of Dandy-Walker continuum who was evaluated in order to investigate her level of cognitive functioning. The case report highlights patterns of deficits in language, memory, and fine motor function in relation to the role of the vermis in motor and cognitive performance.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: This is a case of a 6-year-old girl (the product of a full-term pregnancy and uncomplicated delivery) with the diagnosis of Dandy-Walker continuum and significant expressive language and motor delays. The patient was born full-term, delivered by cesarean section because of a previous cesarean delivery. She weighed 2050 g at birth and remained in the incubator for 4 days. At the age of 16 months, she was admitted to the hospital because of a sudden decrease of the index of increase of the head circumference, which was 41.4 cm (<3rd percentile of the cephalic growth curve). Her weight was also low, 7.9 kg (<3rd percentile), and her length was 74 cm (23rd percentile). Medical history was otherwise unremarkable and there was no family history of any heritable or neurologic disorder. Her older brother by 5 years is a physically and cognitively healthy child. The patient met her motor milestones late: she sat at 12 months of age, and at 16 months she was still supported in order to change steps and was unable to stand unassisted. She smiled, recognized persons, and had adequate ocular pursuit. On physical examination, isolated mild facial dysmorphic features were detected in the form of a depressed nasal bridge (without an uptilted nasal tip or anteverted nares) and a long philtrum. However, there was no evidence of hirsutism, synophrys, long eyelashes, or of a thin upper lip with downturned corners of the mouth, or posteriorly rotated low-set ears in the context of Cornelia de Lange syndrome. Eczema in the face was noted. Additional findings included single horizontal crease of the palms and hypoplastic nipples. Apart from hypermobile joints, a hump in the left thoracic area, and a deviation of the gluteal fissure to the left, no overt upper limb reduction or severe limb anomalies were observed. On neurologic examination, findings were limited to mild left-hand finger-to-nose ataxia. Saccades and pupillary reflexes were preserved. No papilledema or nystagmus was present. There was absence of hypotonia or long tract signs/corticospinal deficits. Overall, the motor strength was normal. Symmetrical muscle strength was grade 4 (Medical Research Council Scale) in proximal upper extremities and grade 5 in lower extremities. Symmetrical deep tendon reflexes and downgoing plantar responses were noted bilaterally. Gait was mildly unsteady and all sensory examinations were normal. Biochemical studies in serum, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid, including electrolytes, liver function tests, lactate and pyruvate, amino acids, and immunologic studies were normal. Electroencephalography was unremarkable. Hearing was normal according to an examination conducted at a children’s hospital.

The patient has been receiving speech and language therapy, as well as occupational therapy and other supportive therapies. She has been attending a regular kindergarten with the support of a special education teacher, where she has adapted well, and is independent in most daily self-help activities. She is clumsy in her movements, unsteady, and exhibits mirror movements/synkinesis when she moves one hand. She is right-hand dominant. The patient is a cooperative, sociable child exhibiting no autistic features.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies show hypoplasia of the vermis, mainly involving its inferior portion, and communication of the fourth ventricle with a cyst in the posterior fossa, without evidence of changes in the thalamus, basal ganglia, midbrain, pons, or medulla, consistent with the diagnosis of Dandy-Walker continuum (Figures 1 and 2). 2 Aside from a small, focal abnormal signal detected on T2-weighted images in the deep periventricular white matter adjoining the left trigone, without overt destructive lesions or bulk diminution of the ipsilateral parieto-occipital white matter or the splenium of the corpus callosum (not shown), no other anatomic abnormalities were identified throughout the neuraxis.

caption.p: A-C, Parasagittal, T1-weighted MR images of the patient’s supra- and infratentorial brain showing cerebellar hypoplasia mainly involving the inferior vermis with abnormal communication between an enlarged fourth ventricle and the cisterna magna. D-F, Small cerebellar vermis in T2-weighted axial rostrocaudal MR images.

Serial coronal T1-weighted inversion recovery sequence MR images of the patient’s supra- and infratentorial brain revealing hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, more prominent in the inferior vermis. There is no evidence of supratentorial developmental abnormalities, encephaloclastic, or overt destructive lesions.

sec.p: A neuropsychological evaluation was recommended in order to investigate the patient’s cognitive and linguistic functions. The girl was cooperative during the evaluation but exhibited an extremely short attention span and easily lost track of the tasks. The neuropsychological evaluation, administered by the first author, revealed the following findings.

sec.title: General Cognitive Function
sec.p: The patient exhibited significant delays on a test of visual reasoning and fluid intelligence, the Raven Coloured Progressive Matrices, 17 scoring below the 5th percentile. She was able to sort cards displaying simple geometric designs of different colors and shapes into groups, 18 both by color and by shape, which indicates intact basic categorization ability. However, she lost track of the task when the number of categories or items per category became greater than 3, which apparently taxed her processing resources.

sec.title: Language
sec.p: Language production was very impaired and affected her ability to verbally communicate her needs. Her speech was mostly unintelligible out of context and was characterized by lack of consonants and imprecise vowels. When naming pictures, she produced the words in segments consisting of vowel approximations, which corresponded to the number of syllables of the word, with the stress on the correct segment. She was able to produce in this manner up to 5-syllable words. Performance on a receptive picture vocabulary test 19 was slightly reduced. Her comprehension of instructions 20 was adequate when she had to process and respond to 1 dimension only, for example, size, but was impaired when she was asked to process and respond to 2 and 3 dimensions simultaneously, for example, size and color.

sec.title: Memory
sec.p: The girl’s memory for faces, both immediate and delayed, was within normal limits. The task requires remembering a set of faces and recognizing them out of a larger set of faces immediately and after a delay. 20 Her immediate recall of spatial positions was, however, deficient: she had considerable difficulty remembering the positions of 5 tokens, placed on a 3 × 4 matrix, immediately after they were presented 21 and was unable to attain correct performance by the fifth trial.

sec.title: Visual Perception
sec.p: Performance on a test of judgment of line orientation, where she had to look at an array of arrows around a target and indicate the 2 arrows that point to the center of the target 20 could not be performed mentally without tracing the extensions of the arrows with her fingers. She was able to perform adequately only when allowed to do so.

sec.title: Visual-Motor Function
sec.p: Performance on a design-copying task, 22 which she executed with the right hand, places her at the age of approximately 3 years 6 months. She had difficulty copying designs that required the crossing of lines and the formation of angles and diagonal lines. Furthermore, she had great difficulty reproducing, from models and from pictures, block constructions in 3 dimensions, 20 even with greater time allowance. She also had great difficulty in a fine motor task of eye-hand coordination that requires drawing a line inside a track as quickly as possible 20 and tended to draw beyond the track lines of the second, more demanding track.

sec.title: Motor Function
sec.p: The patient executed a series of movements predominantly with the right hand in a hand preference task. Movements requiring fine motor control were executed adequately: she was able to cut with scissors, to put a piece of string through a large needle hole, etc. A test of finger dexterity 20 showed adequate execution of simple movements but great difficulty with the complex movements: she was able to tap her index finger against the thumb 32 times quickly, with both the right and the left hand, albeit with mirroring movements. She was, however, unable, to tap the fingers sequentially against the thumb from index to little finger, and attempted to perform this task with the aid of the other hand.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Neuropsychological assessment of a 6-year-old girl with Dandy-Walker continuum revealed cognitive difficulties indicating mild mental retardation, but variability in some areas of performance. The patient showed adequate memory for faces, immediate and delayed, but great difficulty in visual spatial short-term memory and visual perception. Visual motor performance was very impaired, as expected. Fine motor function was adequate for handling objects and for rapid index finger-thumb opposition but not for sequential finger to thumb opposition. Language production was considerably inferior to language comprehension: her speech was severely dysarthric, without any identifiable consonants and was unintelligible out of context. In comparison, milder difficulties were observed in children with confirmed diagnoses of isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia, tested at an average age of 20 months, compared with children with normal postnatal MRI and only 3 infants with isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia and mild hypotonia had gross and fine motor and expressive language delays that were considered clinically significant (1.5 SD below the normative means). 8

Historically, the cerebellum was considered to have exclusively a motor-related function. However, additional roles of the cerebellum, beyond the well-known motor control functions have emerged during the past decade. 13,14,23 Such functions include an expanded role of the cerebellum in sensorimotor control, 24 language, 25 cognition/intellect, emotion, and behavior. 24 The recognition that the cerebellum is involved in multiple aspects of cognitive function raises many challenging questions. Among them is the intriguing, but controversial, role of cerebellum in mental illness, especially in schizophrenia, 26,27 autism, and mental retardation. 28,29

Nonmotor functional deficits are more difficult to detect but are being increasingly recognized in individuals with divergent pathologies largely restricted to the cerebellum, referred to as the cerebellar cognitive affective syndrome. 30 The latter has been observed in adults and children with stroke, tumors, cerebellar degeneration, in developmental cerebellar malformations (hypoplasia and agenesis), and in children born very premature with disproportionately small cerebella. 24,30,31

Neurobehavioral derangements and neurocognitive deficits may occur in the absence of typical motor control abnormalities and may become manifest when pathological lesions involve the posterior lobes of the cerebellar hemispheres. 24 Deficits in the following functions may be encountered: (a) Executive function (planning, verbal fluency, abstract reasoning, working memory); (b) spatial cognition (visual spatial organization and memory); and (c) linguistic processing. 24 Moreover, patients with the cerebellar cognitive affective syndrome, including children with cerebellar tumors, experience emotional changes when their cancerous lesions encroach on or infiltrate the vermis. 24,31

Cerebellar connections with the cerebral cortex are organized into discrete circuits or loops, with each loop involved in a distinct aspect of behavior. Both the dentate nucleus and the cerebellar cortex are organized into separate motor and nonmotor domains, and damage to different areas is predicted to lead to different types of deficits. 13,32 The association areas in the prefrontal cortex are linked predominantly with crus I and II of the cerebellar posterior lobe but also with vermian lobules VII and X and damage to these areas is predicted to result in planning and working memory deficits. M1, on the other hand, receives input from lobules HIV to HVI. 32 In support of this prediction, increased ipsilateral activation was present in lobules HIV to HVI and HVIII during touching the thumb to each finger in sequence repetitively, 33,34 whereas increased bilateral activation was present in the superior cerebellar hemispheres, portions of posterior vermis (VI and VIIa) and the right inferior cerebellar hemisphere HVIIb during a working memory task. 34 The girl showed both considerable working memory problems and inability to perform the above finger-tapping task, consistent with the hypoplasia of the posterior and inferior vermis and inferior cerebellar hemispheres (HVIIa, HVIIb, HVIII, HXIX) (Figure 2).

The intact memory for faces, immediate and delayed, and the deficient immediate memory for spatial positions point to a specific deficit in short-term spatial memory rather than a generalized immediate memory deficit. Memory for faces is based on the encoding of the identity of faces by neurons in the inferior temporal cortex, which have considerable invariance with respect to position, size, and view. 35 The neural correlates of spatial memory for locations, on the other hand, include the occipital extrastriate, posterior-inferior parietal, dorsolateral premotor, and prefrontal cortices. 36 The cerebellar posterior lobe and inferior vermis are linked with prefrontal cortices 32 and the lateral cerebellum is activated as part of a widely distributed circuitry that includes prefrontal areas during a visual spatial working memory task. 37

The inability of the girl reported herein to produce intelligible speech is notable in view of the extent of the hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis. The cerebellum is assumed to engage in the precise representation of temporal information, contributing to fine temporal details for speech motor control. 38,39 It has strong bidirectional connections with the left inferior frontal gyrus and left lateral temporal cortex and is involved in amplification and refinement of phonological representations 40 and the control of sequential movements. 41 Overt production of speech sequences without linguistic meaning activates the superior cerebellar hemispheres, indicating cerebellar involvement in ongoing control of the articulators through crossed thalamocortical projections to the motor cortex and/or direct connections with the periphery. 42 Projections from premotor to primary motor cortex are supplemented by cerebellar projections and constitute feedforward motor commands for syllable production. The paravermal region of the cerebellum is involved in providing the precisely timed feedforward commands necessary for fluent speech. 43 The inferior cerebellum appears to be engaged in motor execution and the superior cerebellum in prearticulatory mechanisms of verbal communication. 38 The girl’s hypoplasia of the inferior vermis appears to have disrupted the execution of speech motor commands. Phonation was possible, and it is associated with dentate nucleus activation. 44 Her correct vowel stress placement in her utterances indicates the presence of some prearticulatory representations.

An inability to form intelligible speech sounds associated with cerebellar hypoplasia of the vermis is rarely reported in the literature, especially in the context of considerably higher receptive language and other cognitive functions. Three brothers with severe hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis and hemispheres showed psychomotor delay, ataxia, clumsiness, hypotonia, ocular signs, and speech delay but were able to combine words or even speak in simple sentences. 4 Two children with hypoplasia of the vermis, for whom psychological evaluations were available, out of 11 children with nonprogressive, nonsyndromic isolated cerebellar hypoplasia from a retrospective review of a pediatric database, were able to produce speech. One child showed borderline developmental scores and delay in motor, language, and reasoning skills, and the other showed reading difficulties, a short attention span, low average IQ, poor memory, and perceptual and verbal difficulties. Another child from the series showed severe speech delay and poor social skills, which were associated with the diagnosis of Pervasive Developmental Delay. 5 A woman with almost complete absence of the cerebellum was able to speak, albeit with mild to moderate dysarthria. 45 On the other hand, transient cerebellar mutism can be observed after surgery in children with cerebellar tumors and is associated with lesions primarily in the posterior inferior vermis, with more frequent and more expansive involvement of the dentate nuclei. 46

A dissociation between adequate phonation and severely disturbed execution of articulatory movements associated with consonant production appears to parallel the girl’s difficulty performing a sequential finger-tapping task but not a repetitive one, indicating a common neurologic substrate for the 2 forms of motor control. Both speech and finger movements are partly subserved by the same cerebellar areas. A repetitive tongue movement task, repetition of the syllables “da-da,” and a sequential finger-tapping task show overlap in cerebellar activation that involves both interposed nuclei, the ipsilateral dentate nucleus, and the vermis and paravermis. 47

From the standpoint of differential diagnosis, the patient’s history of growth retardation coupled with mild facial dysmorphic features call attention to the exclusion of Cornelia de Lange syndrome, which is characterized by growth retardation of a prenatal onset, followed by persisting difficulties in weight and height gain during the postnatal period as well as abnormal psychomotor development and behavioral findings. 48,49 Rare instances of cerebellar vermian hypoplasia associated with other midline brain malformations, 50 or of isolated nonprogressive cerebellar hypoplasia, 51 have been reported in connection with Cornelia de Lange syndrome. Most affected individuals with the classic phenotype of that syndrome have moderate-to-severe mental retardation, whereas borderline-to-mild deficits are usually observed in patients who are mildly affected. 48 Similar, albeit not identical, to the present case, the cognitive profile in Cornelia de Lange syndrome is characterized by delayed verbal communication with specific deficits in expressive language whereas receptive language and verbal comprehension are less affected. Unlike in the present case, visuospatial memory and perceptual organization in Cornelia de Lange syndrome are usually normal. 48 An important distinguishing feature of the present case is that it does not show the typical behavioral manifestations encountered in Cornelia de Lange syndrome such as evidence of daily aggression and hyperactivity, interpersonal relationship difficulties, stereotyped behavior, diminished responsiveness to pain, autistic features, or self-injurious behaviors. 48,49

In conclusion, the present case illustrates the presence of mild mental retardation and lack of intelligible speech in a young girl with Dandy-Walker continuum. Language comprehension was adequate for single items and simple instructions but not for more complex instructions, indicating an auditory short-term memory deficit. Similarly, visual memory was intact for single items but not for the positions of multiple (identical) items, indicating a visual short-term memory deficit as well as a visuospatial deficit, also evidenced by her impaired ability to judge the orientations of different lines. Repetitive finger tapping was adequate but sequential finger tapping was very impaired. The neuropsychological profile suggests considerable processing/short-term memory deficits, which are characteristic of children in the mild mental retardation range. In comparison to the children reported in the literature with Dandy-Walker continuum or isolated inferior vermian hypoplasia, however, the girl presented with absence of intelligible speech but adequate receptive language. The case extends our knowledge of the phenotypes associated with cerebellar hypoplasia and its relation to fine motor and articulatory control. A follow-up of the girl’s language and cognitive development will clarify the relationship between the development of speech and motor control, as well as the more mature phenotype associated with a relatively circumscribed hypoplasia of the cerebellum.
